WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 319 March 1979 EDUCATIONAL AND ECONOMIC EFFECTS OF PROMOTION AND REPETITION PRACTICES This paper presents policies, practices and problems of student flow, and related research findings to the questions: What are the determinants of achievement and their- implications for promotion practices? How valid are the criteria used in promotion decisions? What are the comparative effects of promotion practices on the achievement and personality of pupils? What are the other educational options to deal with failure and low achievement? On the basis of the studies reviewed, it was concluded that (a) the dynamics of success and failure can best be represented by a multidimen- sional interactive matrix of school-related and out-of-school variables; (b) promotion decisions are based on unreliable measures of academic performance and ignore affective and social goals of education; (c) there is no evidence that repetition is more effective than promotion, or that repetition practices improve academic standards and class homogeneity; and (d) grade retention has certain negative effects on a pupil's self-concept and attitude. Although promotion seems to be more desirable than retention, the real issue is that of prevention of failure. Consequently an educational strategy is suggested, the basic elements of which are a nongraded curriculum, ability grouping and a new role for educational measurement. Prepared by: Wadi D. Wastage in the flow of a cohort of students in an educational system is expressed quantitatively in terms of dropout and repetition. Dropout is considered wasteful because of the investment of educational services and economic resources in pupils who fail to complete a cycle, particularly those who drop out before the minimum for permanent literacy is achieved. It also contributes to under-utilization of-physical facili- ties as a result of a decrease in class size in successive grades within a cycle. Repetition is regarded as wasteful since repeaters stay in school longer than the normal duration and thus reduce the intake capacity of the corresponding grades and increase the education unit costs. 2. There are two major rubrics under which policies regarding dynamics of student flow fall: repetition (retention), and automatic promotion. However., the application of components of such policies generates a wide spectrut of diversified systems. Countries that systematically practice repetition differ in terms of (a) criteria used for promotion, (b) the person or body that is responsible for deciding on promotion, (c) the control of the number of years that a pupil is permitted to be retained in a particular grade, and (d) the academic treatment given to repeaters. Similarly, appli- cation of automatic promotion varies in terms of scope, justification and remedial work that accompanies it.

A large number of studies have been conducted to test the effects of promotion practices on achievement, scholastic standards and class homo- geneity'. Some of these studies attempted to test the assumption that repeti- tion of a grade significantly increases the achievement level of the repeater. The results of a survey conducted by the Bangkok Institute for Child Study in 1966 of 25,000 school children concluded that repetition of grades appeared to hold no advantage in raising achievement levels (Phillips, 1975). The first element in such a strategy is a re-definition of cur- riculum in terms of schooling years. The division of the teaching/learning process into units of one year duration called grades that have to be passed in bulk is an arbitrary decision. Since learning is a continuous process and does not occur in discrete steps, it is more realistic to break the curriculum into smaller units approaching a continuum. Then threshold levels of achievement may be defined in a sequential pattern, the feedback circuit will be short and manageable, and repetition, if necessary, becomes purposeful and efficient. Structurally, this strategy leads to the concept of non-graded curriculum. doc.repnme: Educational and economic effects on promotion and repetition practices
doc.abstracts: This paper presents policies, practices and problems of student flow, and related research findings to the questions: What are the determinants of achievement and their implications for promotion practices? How valid are the criteria used in promotion decisions? What are the comparative effects of promotion practices on the achievement and personality of pupils? What are the other educational options to deal with failure and low achievement? On the basis of the studies reviewed, it was concluded that: (a) the dynamics of success and failure can best be represented by a multidimensional interactive matrix of school-related and out-of-school variables; (b) promotion decisions are based on unreliable measures of academic performance and ignore affective and social goals of education; (c) there is no evidence that repetition is more effective than promotion, or that repetition practices improve academic standards and class homogeneity; and (d) grade retention has certain negative effects on a pupil's self-concept and attitude.
